Brava! Jefferson Traditional Middle School's Dawn Forsythe (pictured fourth from left) received the prestigious Quinlan & Fabish Music Company Michiana Outstanding Music Educator Award.

Forsythe is in her 28th year of teaching band. She took John Adams Marching Band (1996-2010) to six appearances in the Open Class ISSMA Regional Marching Band Competition earning gold ratings and the John Adams Jazz Ensemble won honor band status two times as well as multiple soloist and section awards at the Purdue Jazz Festival.

Because of increased enrollment of band students, she transferred to Jefferson in 2013 where she started a Jazz Ensemble which received honors at the
Plymouth Jazz Festival in 2015. The Jefferson Cadet and Concert Bands won ISSMA gold for the first time in school history in 2017 and the ISSMA All Band Award in 2018.

Dr. C. Todd Cummings, Superintendent of South Bend Community School Corporation, has been named one of 25 “Superintendents to Watch” nationally by the National Schools Public Relations Association (NSPRA) for “demonstrating dynamic, fast-paced leadership with strong communication at its core.”

Cummings was recognized for his innovative and effective use of communication technology to engage and inform the school community and for expanding two-way communication outreach efforts. Monthly (virtual) community-wide “Talks with Todd,” weekly videos and automated dialers, and Wi-Fi-equipped school buses are some of the innovative communications initiatives implemented under Cummings.

As part of the recognition, Cummings will be featured in an upcoming issue of the NSPRA’s online publication “This Week,” and as a special guest at the NSPRA National Seminar in New Orleans in July 2021.

Cummings formally began his tenure as Superintendent for South Bend Community School in July of 2019.

Based on the increased engagement with parents, students, and community members generated by virtual “Talks with Todd,” South Bend Community School Corporation Superintendent Dr. C. Todd Cummings plans to continue the events online through the end of the calendar year, beginning Tuesday, June 30 at 9:00 a.m.

“Talks with Todd” have been virtual since schools closed in mid-March, and the online events have generated more than ten times the number of participants than the in-person, monthly events. The first Facebook Live event held on April 14 has reached more than 3,000 individual Facebook accounts to date.

“It’s clear that conducting ‘Talks with Todd’ using Facebook Live generates much more engagement than the in-person events do,” Cumming said. “Since regular, open communication with parents, staff, and students continues to be a priority, it just makes good sense to continue the virtual events.” See the schedule: http://sb.school/news/talks_with_todd_to_continue

As of right now, all Indiana school buildings are required to remain closed to the public through the end of the academic year, which the state defines as June 30. For that reason, South Bend Superintendent Todd Cummings said staff and students are not allowed to re-enter buildings until later this summer.

Teachers can return to buildings to collect or drop off belongings on July 1. High school students can enter schools on July 7, middle school students on July 8 and elementary students on July 9.

Everyone is required to wear a mask and follow social distancing guidelines.

Additionally, graduating seniors will be able drop off textbooks and Chromebooks and pick up their caps and gowns after June 3. Cummings said principals will contact students with more details, including event dates and times.

For the first time in South Bend Community School Corporation history, four students are graduating from high school and already have associate college degrees from Ivy Tech Community College South Bend-Elkhart.

"It was one of my priorities to enhance our relationship with Ivy Tech and ensure that our students could have the opportunity to earn an associate degree concurrently with high school graduation,” said Superintendent Dr. Todd Cummings.

Students split their time between the ASAP program at Ivy Tech and their high schools. This afforded students the opportunity to earn dual credit from Ivy Tech and their high school. The Ivy Tech ASAP program provides South Bend Community Schools’ students the opportunity to enter the workforce or a four-year college ahead of most graduating seniors.
http://sb.school/news/students_will_graduate_with_associate_degrees

As of Friday, nearly 27,700 meals have been given to families by South Bend schools.

“We’ve been pretty accurate in projecting the number of meals needed per site by using existing data and being proactive in selecting meal plans that allow for flexibility,” said Kareemah Fowler, the district’s chief financial officer.

Since the district’s regularly-budgeted meals are now combined with the federally-funded summer feeding program, Chief Communications Officer Susan Guibert said, food is being given to “anyone who is hungry,” not just corporation students.
